(10) =1s​∑i=1nu(i)​x1(i)⏟sample dimension SA,…,1s​∑i=1nu(i)​xd(i)⏟sample dimension SAabsentsubscript⏟1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1superscript𝑢𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖1sample dimension SA…subscript⏟1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1superscript𝑢𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑑sample dimension SA\displaystyle=\underbrace{\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{n}_{i=1}u^{(i)}x^{(i)}_{1}}_{{\text{sample dimension SA}}},...,\underbrace{\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{n}_{i=1}u^{(i)}x^{(i)}_{d}}_{{\text{sample dimension SA}}}

To deal with the secure computation task of training loss as described in Algorithm 1, we only apply feature dimension SA approach. As the average loss function here is least-squares function, secure computation involved is as follows:

(11) ℒℬ​(𝒘)=1s​∑i=1s(𝒘⊺​𝒙(i)−y(i)⏟feature dimension SA)2⏟Normal Computationsubscriptℒℬ𝒘1𝑠subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1superscriptsubscript⏟superscript𝒘⊺superscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖feature dimension SA2Normal Computation\begin{split}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{B}}(\boldsymbol{w})&=\tfrac{1}{s}\underbrace{\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}(\underbrace{\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}-y^{(i)}}_{\text{feature dimension SA}})^{2}}_{\text{Normal Computation}}\end{split}

Obviously, the feature dimension SA can satisfy the computation task in the above equation.

A.2. Generalized Linear Models in FedV

Here we formally analyze the details of applying our FedV-SecGrad approach to train generalized linear models in FedV.

We use logistic regression as an example, which has the following fitting (prediction) function:

(12) f​(𝒙;𝒘)=11+e−𝒘⊺​𝒙𝑓𝒙𝒘11superscript𝑒superscript𝒘⊺𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})=\tfrac{1}{1+e^{-\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}}}

For binary label y∈{0,1}𝑦01y\in\{0,1\}, the loss function can be defined as:

(13) ℒ​(f​(𝒙;𝒘),y)={−log⁡(f​(𝒙;𝒘))​if ​y=1−log⁡(1−f​(𝒙;𝒘))​if ​y=0ℒ𝑓𝒙𝒘𝑦cases𝑓𝒙𝒘if 𝑦11𝑓𝒙𝒘if 𝑦0\mathcal{L}(f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}),y)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}-\log(f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}))\;\text{if }y=1\\ -\log(1-f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}))\;\text{if }y=0\end{array}\right.

Then, the total loss over a mini-batch ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of size s𝑠s is computed as follows:

(14) E​(𝒘)𝐸𝒘\displaystyle E(\boldsymbol{w}) =−1s​∑i=1s[y(i)​𝒘⊺​𝒙(i)−log⁡(1+e𝒘⊺​𝒙(i))]absent1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1delimited-[]superscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝒘⊺superscript𝒙𝑖1superscript𝑒superscript𝒘⊺superscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle=-\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}[y^{(i)}\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}-\log(1+e^{\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}})]

The gradient is computed as follows:

(15) ∇E​(𝒘)∇𝐸𝒘\displaystyle\nabla E(\boldsymbol{w}) =1s​∑i=1s[∂∂𝒘​log⁡(1+e𝒘​𝒙(i))−∂y(i)​𝒘​𝒙(i)∂𝒘]absent1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1delimited-[]𝒘1superscript𝑒𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖𝒘\displaystyle=\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}[\tfrac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{w}}\log(1+e^{\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}})-\tfrac{\partial y^{(i)}\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}}{\partial\boldsymbol{w}}]
(16) =1s​∑i=1s(11+e−𝒘​𝒙(i)−y(i))​𝒙(i)absent1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖111superscript𝑒𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle=\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}(\frac{1}{1+e^{-\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}}}-y^{(i)})\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}

Note that we also do not include the regularization term λ​R​(𝒘)𝜆𝑅𝒘\lambda R(\boldsymbol{w}) here for the same aforementioned reason. Here, we show two potential solutions in detail:

(i) FedV for nonlinear model (Procedure 3). Firstly, although the prediction function in (12) is a non-linear function, it can be decomposed as f​(𝒙;𝒘)=g​(h​(𝒙;𝒘))𝑓𝒙𝒘𝑔ℎ𝒙𝒘f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})=g(h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})), where:

(17) g​(h​(𝒙;𝒘))=11+e−h​(𝒙;𝒘)​, where ​h​(𝒙;𝒘)=𝒘⊺​𝒙𝑔ℎ𝒙𝒘11superscript𝑒ℎ𝒙𝒘, where ℎ𝒙𝒘superscript𝒘⊺𝒙g(h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}))=\tfrac{1}{1+e^{-h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})}}\text{, where }h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})=\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}

We can see that the sigmoid function g​(z)=11+e−z𝑔𝑧11superscript𝑒𝑧g(z)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-z}} is not a linear function, while h​(𝒙;𝒘)ℎ𝒙𝒘h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}) is linear. We then apply our feature dimension and sample dimension secure aggregations on linear function h​(𝒙;𝒘)ℎ𝒙𝒘h(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w}) instead. To be more specific, the formal expression of the secure gradient computation is as follows:

∇E​(𝒘)∇𝐸𝒘\displaystyle\nabla E(\boldsymbol{w}) =1s​∑i=1s(11+e−∑jn(upj(i))}→feature dim. SA−y(i))⏟Normal Computation→u(i)​𝒙(i)\displaystyle=\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}\underbrace{(\tfrac{1}{1+e^{-\sum^{n}_{j}(u^{(i)}_{p_{j}})\}\rightarrow\text{feature dim. SA}}}-y^{(i)})}_{\text{Normal Computation}\rightarrow u^{(i)}}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}
(18) =1s​(∑i=1su(i)​x1(i)⏟sample dimension SA,…,∑i=1su(i)​xj(i)⏟sample dimension SA)absent1𝑠subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1superscript𝑢𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖1sample dimension SA…subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1superscript𝑢𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑗sample dimension SA\displaystyle=\tfrac{1}{s}(\underbrace{\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}u^{(i)}x^{(i)}_{1}}_{{\text{sample dimension SA}}},...,\underbrace{\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}u^{(i)}x^{(i)}_{j}}_{{\text{sample dimension SA}}})

Note that the output of feature dimension SA is in plaintext, and hence, the aggregator is able to evaluate the sigmoid function g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) together with the labels. The secure loss can be computed as follows:

E​(𝒘)𝐸𝒘\displaystyle E(\boldsymbol{w}) =−1s∑i=1s[y(i)​𝒘⊺​𝒙(i)⏟feature dim. SA⏟normal computation−\displaystyle=-\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}[\underbrace{y^{(i)}\underbrace{\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}}_{\text{feature dim. SA}}}_{\text{normal computation}}-
(19) log⁡(1+e−𝒘⊺𝒙(i)}→feature dim. SA)⏟normal computation]\displaystyle\;\;\;\;\;\underbrace{\log(1+e^{-\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}\}\rightarrow\text{feature dim. SA}})}_{\text{normal computation}}]

Similar to secure gradient descent computation, however, we only have the feature dimension SA with subsequent normal computation.

(ii) Taylor approximation. FedV also supports the Taylor approximation approach as proposed in [26]. In this approach, the Taylor series expansion of function log⁡(1+e−z)1superscript𝑒𝑧\log(1+e^{-z})=log⁡2−12​z+18​z2+O​(z4)212𝑧18superscript𝑧2𝑂superscript𝑧4\log 2-\frac{1}{2}z+\frac{1}{8}z^{2}+O(z^{4}) is applied to equation (13) to approximately compute the gradient as follows:

(20) ∇Eℬ​(𝒘)≈1s​∑i=1s(14​𝒘⊺​𝒙(i)−y(i)+12)​𝒙(i)∇subscript𝐸ℬ𝒘1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖114superscript𝒘⊺superscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖12superscript𝒙𝑖\nabla E_{\mathcal{B}}(\boldsymbol{w})\approx\frac{1}{s}\sum^{s}_{i=1}(\frac{1}{4}\boldsymbol{w}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}-y^{(i)}+\frac{1}{2})\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}

As in equation (6), we are able to apply the 2Phase-SA approach in the secure computation of equation (20).

We also use another ML model, SVMs with Kernels, as an example. Here, we consider two cases:

(i) linear SVM model for data that is not linearly separable: Suppose that the linear SVM model uses squared hinge loss as the loss function, and hence, its objective is to minimize

(21) E​(𝒘)=1s​∑i=1s(max⁡(0,1−y(i)​𝒘​𝒙(i)))2𝐸𝒘1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1superscript01superscript𝑦𝑖𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖2\displaystyle E(\boldsymbol{w})=\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}\left(\max(0,1-y^{(i)}\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)})\right)^{2}

The gradient can be computed as follows:

(22) ∇E=1s​∑i=1s[−2​y(i)​(max⁡(0,1−y(i)​𝒘​𝒙(i)))​𝒙(i)]∇𝐸1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1delimited-[]2superscript𝑦𝑖01superscript𝑦𝑖𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle\nabla E=\tfrac{1}{s}\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}[-2y^{(i)}(\max(0,1-y^{(i)}\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}))\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}]

As we know, the aggregator can obtain 𝒘​𝒙(i)𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{w}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)} via feature dimension SA. With the provided labels and 𝒘(i)⊺​𝒙(i)superscript𝒘limit-from𝑖⊺superscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{w}^{(i)\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}, FedV-SecGrad can update Line 3 of Procedure 2 so that the aggregator computes ui=−2​y(i)​max⁡(0,1−y(i)​𝒘(i)⊺​𝒙(i))subscript𝑢𝑖2superscript𝑦𝑖01superscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝒘limit-from𝑖⊺superscript𝒙𝑖u_{i}=-2y^{(i)}\max(0,1-y^{(i)}\boldsymbol{w}^{(i)\intercal}\boldsymbol{x}^{(i)}) instead.

(ii) the case where SVM uses nonlinear kernels: The prediction function is as follows:

(23) f​(𝒙;𝒘)=∑i=1swi​yi​k​(𝒙i,𝒙),𝑓𝒙𝒘subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑘subscript𝒙𝑖𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x};\boldsymbol{w})=\textstyle{\sum}^{s}_{i=1}w_{i}y_{i}k(\boldsymbol{x}_{i},\boldsymbol{x}),

where k​(⋅)𝑘⋅k(\cdot) denotes the corresponding kernel function. As nonlinear kernel functions, such as polynomial kernel (𝒙i⊺​𝒙j)dsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒙⊺𝑖subscript𝒙𝑗𝑑(\boldsymbol{x}^{\intercal}_{i}\boldsymbol{x}_{j})^{d}, sigmoid kernel t​a​n​h​(β​𝒙i⊺​𝒙j+θ)𝑡𝑎𝑛ℎ𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝒙⊺𝑖subscript𝒙𝑗𝜃tanh(\beta\boldsymbol{x}^{\intercal}_{i}\boldsymbol{x}_{j}+\theta) (β𝛽\beta and θ𝜃\theta are kernel coefficients), are based on inner-product computation which is supported by our feature dimension SA and sample dimension SA protocols, these kernel matrices can be computed before the training process. And the aforementioned objective for SVM with nonlinear kernels will be reduced to SVM with linear kernel case with the pre-computed kernel matrix. Then the gradient computation process for these SVM models will be reduced to a gradient computation of a standard linear SVM, which can clearly be supported by FedV-SecGrad.

Appendix B Secure Loss Computation in FedV

Unlike the secure loss computation (SLC) protocol in the contrasted VFL framework [26], the SLC approach in FedV is much simpler. Here, we use the logistic regression model as an example. As illustrated in Procedure 4, unlike the SLC in [26] that is separate and different from the secure gradient computation, the SLC here does not need additional operations for the parties. The loss result is computed by reusing the result of the feature dimension SA in the FedV-SecGrad.

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 5.3

Here, we present the specific proof for Lemma 5.3. Given a predefined party group 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} with OTP setting, we have the following claims: Security-except for the released seeds, ∀p′∉𝒫for-allsuperscript𝑝′𝒫\forall p^{{}^{\prime}}\notin\mathcal{P}, p′superscript𝑝′p^{{}^{\prime}} cannot infer the next seed based on released seeds; Randomness-∀pi∈𝒫for-allsubscript𝑝𝑖𝒫\forall p_{i}\in\mathcal{P}, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} can obtain a synchronized and sequence-related one-time seed without peer-to-peer communication with other parties.

Proof of Lemma 5.3.

Since there exist various types of OPT, we adopt the hash chains-based OPT to prove the security and randomness of the OTP-based seed generation. Given the cryptographic hash function H𝐻H, the initial random seed r𝑟r and a sequence index bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} (i.e., the batch index in the FedV training), the OTP-based seed for bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is ri=H(t)​(r)subscript𝑟𝑖superscript𝐻𝑡𝑟r_{i}=H^{(t)}(r). Note that H(t)​(r)=H​(H(t−1)​(r))=…=H​(…​H(1)​(r))superscript𝐻𝑡𝑟𝐻superscript𝐻𝑡1𝑟…𝐻…superscript𝐻1𝑟H^{(t)}(r)=H(H^{(t-1)}(r))=...=H(...H^{(1)}(r)). Next, the OTP-based seed for bi+1subscript𝑏𝑖1b_{i+1} is ri+1=H(t−1)​(r)subscript𝑟𝑖1superscript𝐻𝑡1𝑟r_{i+1}=H^{(t-1)}(r), and hence we have ri=H​(ri+1)subscript𝑟𝑖𝐻subscript𝑟𝑖1r_{i}=H(r_{i+1}). Given the risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} at training index bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, suppose that an adversary has a non-negligible advantage to infer the next ri+1subscript𝑟𝑖1r_{i+1}, the adversary needs to find a way of calculating the inverse function H−1superscript𝐻1H^{-1}. Since the cryptographic hash function should be one-way and proved to be computationally intractable according to the adopted schemes, the adversary does not have the non-negligible advantage to infer the next seed. With respect to the randomness, the initial seed r𝑟r is randomly selected, and the follow-up computation over r𝑟r is a sequence of the hash function, which does not break the randomness of r𝑟r. ∎
